name: places/ChIJiS8ClFlYwokR8-12oMzGq3E
formattedAddress: 423 W 55th St, New York, NY 10019, USA
adrFormatAddress: 423 W 55th St, New York, NY 10019, USA

originalText.text: Dr Lund left me a vm, because he had a question for me before he could release my sleep study. Several weeks later, and many calls to SDI, I still have not heard back. I was told that it was “impossible” for me to speak to Dr Lund, but they would set up a portal for me for the results which do not exist. So frustrating… Do I need to contact my insurance company to file a complaint? Yes.

originalText.text: I've been a patient of Dr Lund for 5 years. I like him alot. He is a strait shooter, and gets to the point. Which I like alot. His office staff are the worst however. Michael the receptionist is only allowed to make appointments, and is not authorized to leave a message for the doctor. Several voicemails with supervisors, including Susan go unanswered. I had to file a complaint with my insurance company that they dont allow me to talk to my doctor, to finally get my sleep results.

originalText.text:
Like many others who reviewed him, Dr Lund spoke to me in a very condescending tone. Instead of being helpful, he ended up judging and berating me.  I have been nothing but soft-spoken, courteous, and open with him, and yet he reacted the opposite. I will no longer see him or Sleep Disorder Institute.

Edit: please resolve all insurance-related issues with the front desk before you leave. The receptionists are supposed to contact your insurance company to determine what you owe at the time of visit.  Instead, they send you off, assuring you that the bill/copay is settled. Several months later, they send you a bill for what the insurance company didn't cover... And what they SHOULD'VE requested during the visit. That means they're being lazy.

originalText.text: I a a registered nurse,  in critical care for 35 years.  I consider myself very capable of assessing the attitudes and the knowledge bases of physicians.  I will tell you that Dr. Lund has a fine attitude and a friendly demeanor toward the patient. AND, as one of a rare group of certified sleep specialists, he has knowledge and insight into sleep disorders that, I believe, goes far beyond what physicians from other disciplines have to offer. the  I not understand how a number of patients gave Dr. Lund only one star.  I will not make accusations, only speculations:  At times, patients "go shopping" for the answers that they want for certain questions. When the doc finds that the desired response, treatment, etc is inappropriate, and will not provide it, the patient then turns against the doctor.  In conclusion, go see Dr. Lund, if you have difficulty sleeping.

originalText.text:
My initial interaction with Dr. Lund was great. He made me feel really hopeful about getting an answer about my fatigue. We set up a plan of symptoms to track that he identified as well as a plan to prepare for a sleep study.

In the follow up after the sleep study, he disregarded all data I had collected and gave me a diagnosis that doesn't make sense given my symptoms and the insufficient data he has (one conclusion he made would require further tracking of sleep schedules to regulate it and the removal of variables). When I brought up the symptom tracker he had asked for, he said he doesn't know what it was I experienced (without even looking at it), but it wasn't that because I don't have the condition and that I should go to a psychiatrist. Despite the only condition linked to that symptom being very finicky with sleep studies. My constant fatigue was pinned on mild apnea (which was so mild he didn't recommend treating it and it showed up on only 1 of 4 sleep studies I've had in the past year) and told that he wouldn't continue working with me. Very disheartening since I am in my early 20's and no matter what I do, how much I regulate sleep, am constantly fatigued.
